content: this legal case involves a coownership property dispute that started in 2008 and lasted for 5 years and 9 months the court decided that the property should be dissolved and sold through a public auction with the sale value divided among the parties based on their coownership ratios the plaintiff would receive 46 of the sale value while the defendants would each receive 16 the defendants argued that the plaintiffs claim for dissolution should have been handled outside of court but the court disagreed and granted the plaintiffs claim the court determined that the property should be physically and geometrically divided according to the coownership ratios but if division would significantly reduce the value a public auction was the appropriate method expert opinions confirmed that the property was a highrise residential building with two separate units and a garage the court decided that the plaintiff would receive the apartment on the high ground floor and the defendants would receive the apartment in the basement in a way that corresponds to the ideal values indicated in the land register the plaintiff disagreed with the appellants proposed method of partitioning and objected to establishing condominium ownership therefore the court applied the law and determined that the property should be sold at a public auction with the sale price distributed proportionally among the coowners
